sols_html:
Using the ratio test seems appropriate here. If we denote the general term of the series by

\[\begin{aligned} a_k = \frac{k(k+1)}{2^k} \quad\text{for all } k \geq 1\end{aligned}\]

Then the ratio test asks us to look at

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{a_{k+1}}{a_k} &= \frac{(k+1)(k+2)2^k}{k(k+1)2^{k+1}}\\ &= \frac{k+2}{2k}\end{aligned}\]

(Note: we removed the absolute value since the terms are clearly all positive). And so

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{k \to \infty} \frac{a_{k+1}}{a_k} = \lim_{k \to \infty}\frac{k+2}{2k} = \frac{1}{2}\end{aligned}\]

Since this is a number less than one, the ratio test guarantees that the series converges absolutely.
